title: RL32616
content: The 9/11 Commission found that key officials responsible for alien admissions were not fully involved in counterterrorism efforts before September 11, 2001, leading to missed opportunities to intercept the terrorists. The report highlighted various vulnerabilities in al Qaeda's travel methods and made recommendations related to immigration law and policy. The 9/11 Commission issued recommendations regarding immigration law and policy, emphasizing the importance of targeting terrorist travel and enhancing border security. These recommendations have broad implications for immigration-related reforms as Congress acts on them. The 9/11 Commission issued recommendations to collaborate with other governments to prevent terrorist entry. Immigration-related reforms were a key focus in the 108th Congress, with two bills passing that proposed revisions to immigration law. These bills faced contention among lawmakers, delaying a compromise bill. The Senate passed S. 2845 on October 8, 2004, with immigration provisions causing contention among lawmakers. The conference report on S. 2845 was passed by the House on December 7 and the Senate on December 8, 2004. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 (P.L. 108-458) was signed on December 17, 2004, incorporating some immigration provisions. The focus was on identifying and intercepting terrorists entering or leaving the US, in line with the 9/11 Commission's recommendations. Congress had previously mandated an automated entry and exit data system for aliens, which has not been fully implemented. Following the 9/11 Commission's recommendations, Congress enacted measures such as the USA PATRIOT Act and the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Reform Act to expedite the development of an automated entry and exit data system. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 required a pre-inspection program at selected overseas locations to inspect aliens before their departure to the United States. Various proposals in the 108th Congress aimed to enhance the accurate monitoring of individuals entering or leaving the country. Immigration officers inspect aliens before their final departure to the United States and provide assistance to air carriers at selected foreign airports to detect fraudulent documents. Proposals in the 108th Congress aimed to improve monitoring of persons entering and exiting the US, including the development of a biometric entry and exit data system integrated with databases, pre-flight comparison of passenger records with terrorist watch lists, and the establishment of a watchlist for cruise ship passengers. DHS was authorized to establish permanent pre-enrollment programs for participants. The 108th Congress proposed measures to enhance security for travelers entering the US, including implementing an appeals process for record modification, establishing a watchlist for cruise ship passengers, improving passport security, adopting international name translation standards, expanding pre-inspection programs, and enhancing visa issuance security through training for consular officers and immigration inspectors. The 108th Congress proposed measures to enhance security for travelers entering the US, including improving the security of the visa issuance process by providing training to consular officers and immigration inspectors in detecting terrorist indicators, terrorist travel patterns, and fraudulent documents. This involved establishing an Office of Visa and Passport Security within the State Department, increasing the number of consular officers, codifying that all temporary visa applications be adjudicated by a consular officer, providing more training in detecting fraudulent documents, and stationing anti-fraud specialists at consular posts overseas. Additionally, the Congress required persons applying for nonimmigrant visas between the ages of 12 and 65 to be interviewed by a consular officer prior to visa issuance, with a waiver possible in certain circumstances. It also includes provisions for the removal of aliens involved in genocide, torture, or religious freedom violations abroad. The 9/11 Commission recommended national standards for the issuance of birth certificates to prevent fraud. The 9/11 Commission recommended national standards for the issuance of birth certificates and drivers' licenses to prevent fraudulent acquisition, in response to concerns about terrorist aliens acquiring U.S. identification documents for terrorist activities. The adoption of national standards for identification has been controversial and linked with immigration legislation. Congress provided standards for acceptance of state drivers' licenses and birth certificates for federal purposes, but the provision was repealed in 2000 due to concerns about a national identification card. Post-9/11, proposals were made to increase federal oversight and security of state-issued identification documents. In response to the 9/11 Commission's recommendations, proposals were made to increase federal oversight and improve the security of state-issued identification documents, including drivers' licenses, birth certificates, and Social Security documents. These proposals aimed to bar federal agencies from accepting state-issued documents that do not meet national minimum standards for security and information features. The national minimum standards for state-issued identification documents include features on drivers' licenses, identification cards, and birth certificates. Federal agencies are prohibited from accepting documents that do not meet these standards. Audits are conducted to ensure state compliance, and grants are contingent on interstate participation. Additionally, there are proposals to improve the application process for newborn Social Security numbers and study the requirement for photographic identification for Social Security numbers. It also addresses grounds for removal related to visa revocation and prohibits aliens involved in genocide, torture, extrajudicial killing, or severe violations of religious freedom. Additionally, the act mandates a study on weaknesses in the U.S. asylum system exploited by terrorists. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act increases resources for border security, including more agents for the northern border, ICE investigators, and immigration detention beds. It also establishes pilot programs for advanced technologies and surveillance along the borders. Penalties for alien smuggling are also increased, with outreach programs to educate the public on the consequences.
